Posts.Content: Sabine Has anyone from the medical team told you that you have the genes that would cause you to probably develop breast cancer in the other breast?  Does your family have a history of breast cancer?  I know that it seems easy like the easiest solutions is to just take them both and get it over with but you need to be sure there is just cause for doing so.  I agree that since your have larger breast it maybe better to do both but a good reconstructive surgeon can help you adjust and ultimately even you out if you just remove one breast.  Do not jump to removing both breast unless you have to.

Posts.Content: On Sep 27, 2011 11:22 PM DickC wrote: I have a rash from Neulasta booster shot given after second chemo treatment for breast cancer. Anyone else have this problem? I am taking Prednisone 50mg tabs. This rash is ferociuos loking, and itches like mad. I never experienced it but I saw another women who sat with me in the Chemo room experience a similar reaction.  Tell your oncologist they have other medicine that will treat it.  The rash is most likely a reaction to both Chemo and the Neulasta combined.

Posts.Content: On Sep 26, 2011 2:13 PM Aranka wrote: My very close friend (childhood friend) was treated for breast cancer several years ago. She lives in Geneva, Switzerland. Just recently she has been diagnozed with metastatic breast cancer. It appears that she has developed a secondary spot on her spine.  Her lymph notes are not involved.  She has undergone both radiation and chemo and to my great sadness her condition has not improved all that much.  She has been and I believe still is treated for severe bone pain, but her pain is not subsiding.  She has to sleep in a special bed and is currently taking cortisone to help her with the "overall bone ache throughout her body" (at least that is how she describes the pain).  I am very concerned for her.  This illness is making her suffer and it is so unfair. She is a great person and despite everything she is going through, she maintains her optimism and hope.  My question is:  what can we, her friends and family, expect in the future and how hopeful can we be about her life expectancy.  I am hoping against hope that her condition will improve, that this is just a temporary set-back.  Her sister is beyond herself with worry and I am just trying to find enough information about her condition.  I know that each case has to be treated separately, but an overall information would be so helful.   Many thanks,   Aranka Aranka, Continue your search for information online about bone cancer especially in the spine. Your friends attitude is going to carry her a long way.  She will sustain herself by staying positive and hopeful.  You must enjoy her life with her one day at a time.  If you do it that way then you may look up and find that she is still here 5 years later then 10 years later.  Enjoy what you have with her and do not worry about how much longer.  Worry is not going to help or change the situation. So be proactive and plan things that can be done to help her enjoy the life she has now.  Change your question to What can we, her friends and family, do now to make sure her life is rich and fulfilling today?

Posts.Content: On Sep 27, 2011 11:05 PM fwfcsoccermom wrote: I have an appointment in a few days with my doctor ~ so I am being proactive.  I was wondering though... should I be freaked out?  I was diagnosed with Hodgkins Lymphoma in 2003 and went through chemo and radiation.  The doctors told me that the radiation that I was exposed to on my chest increased my chances of breast cancer.  NOW... 8 years later I am having these issues.  I am scared to death!!! Do you actually feel any lumps in your breast?  That is one of the indicators of tumors.  Do not panick yet the swelling and tenderness could be a side effect of many things.  Just be prepared just in case cancer is mentioned.  You did not mention your age Could you be pregnant? :)
